fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Intersection of family of sets
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.4
MML setfam_1:def 1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F be a family of sets (i.e., a set whose members are all sets). We define the Intersection of F to be the set \bigcap F such that for all objects x we have x\in \bigcap F iff for each set Y\in F we have x\in Y.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Relative complement of a set
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.5
MML xboole_0:def 5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X and Y be sets. We define the Relative complement of X with respect to Y to be the set Y\setminus X such that for all objects x we have x\in Y\setminus X iff x\in Y and x\notin X.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Complement of a subset
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.5
MML subset_1:def 4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a subset of Y. We define the Complement of X to be the subset X^{\complement } of Y equal to Y\setminus X.
Some texts use \complement X or X' for the complement of X.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Powerset
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.5
MML zfmisc_1:def 1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set. We define the Powerset of X to be the set \mathcal {P}(X) such that for any set Z we have Z\in \mathcal {P}(X) iff Z\subseteq X. That is to say, the powerset of X is the set of all subsets of X.

For finite sets (especially small sets we can write out by hand), we can see this is a sensible thing to define. But for infinite sets, some Mathematicians historically were nervous about this being well-defined. The important thing is that we assert (either axiomatically or dogmatically) this is indeed a set.
(In ZFC, this is given as an axiom.)
Let x and y be objects. Let a and b be objects. We expect the ordered pair (x,y) to be such that: (x,y)=(a,b) if and only if x=a and y=b.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ordered pairs
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.6
MML tarski:def 5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let x and y be objects. We define the Ordered Pair to be the object (x,y) = \{\{x\},\{x,y\}\}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ordered pairs implement their specification
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.6
MML xtuple_0:1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let a, b, c, d be objects. If (a,b)=(c,d), then a=c and b=d.
We boild this proof down to two cases: either c=d or not. We assume (a,b)=(c,d).
Case 1: c=d. Then (c,d)=(c,c)=\{\{c,c\},\{c\}\}=\{\{c\}\} and (a,b)=\{\{a,b\},\{a\}\}=\{\{c\}\} requires \{a,b\}=\{c\} which implies a=b=c. Hence a=b=c=d which implies a=c and b=d as desired.
Case 2: c\neq d. Then \{a\}\neq \{c,d\}, so \{a\}=\{c\}, which means a=c. Then we see (a,b)=(c,b)=(c,d) which implies \{c,b\}=\{c,d\} which means b=d. Hence a=c and b=d.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cartesian product of two sets
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.6
MML zfmisc_1:def 2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X and Y be sets. We define their Cartesian product to be the set X\times Y such that for all objects z, we have z\in X\times Y if and only if there exists objects x and y such that x\in X and y\in Y and z=(x,y).
Let X, Y, Z be sets. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: X\times Y=\emptyset iff X=\emptyset or Y=\emptyset
If X\times Y=Y\times X, then X=Y

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Basis of vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 2.26
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 5.3.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let v_{1},…,v_{m}\in V be vectors. We say B=\{v_{1},…,v_{m}\} is a Basis of V if B is linearly independent and \mathrm {span}(B)=V.
Compare this to Basis of Vector Space from elementary linear algebra.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Basis reduction theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 2.30
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 5.3.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If V=\mathrm {span}(v_{1},…,v_{m}), then either \{v_{1},…,v_{m}\} forms a basis of V or some v_{i} can be removed to obtain a basis of V.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Basis extension theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 2.32
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 5.3.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Every linearly independent set in a finite-dimensional vector space V can be extended to a basis of V.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Bijective functions have unique inverse
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML funct_1:def 5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon X\to Y be an Bijective function. Then there exists a function g\colon Y\to X such that f\circ g=\mathop {\mathrm {id}}\nolimits _{Y} and g\circ f=\mathop {\mathrm {id}}\nolimits _{X}. Moreover this function g is unique.
We call such a g the Inverse of f, and we usually denote it by f^{-1}=g.
We see that if (x,y)\in f, then (y,x)\in g.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cartesian product of two sets
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.6
MML zfmisc_1:def 2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X and Y be sets. We define their Cartesian product to be the set X\times Y such that for all objects z, we have z\in X\times Y if and only if there exists objects x and y such that x\in X and y\in Y and z=(x,y).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Complement of a subset
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.5
MML subset_1:def 4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a subset of Y. We define the Complement of X to be the subset X^{\complement } of Y equal to Y\setminus X.
Some texts use \complement X or X' for the complement of X.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Complex exponential
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 2.3.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z=x+\mathrm {i} y be a complex number with x,y\in \mathbb {R}. Then we define the Complex Exponential to be a function \exp \colon \mathbb {C}\to \mathbb {C} defined by \exp (z)=\mathrm {e}^{x}\mathrm {e}^{\mathrm {i} y}=\mathrm {e}^{x}(\cos (y)+\mathrm {i}\sin (y))

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Complex sine and cosine
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 2.3.4

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Set of complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics §2.1
Linear Algebra Done Right 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We define the Set of Complex Numbers \mathbb {C}=\{(x,y)\mid x,y\in \mathbb {R}\}. Given a complex number z=(x,y), we call \Re (z)=x the Real Part of z, and \Im (z)=y the Imaginary Part of z.
We write \mathrm {i}=(0,1) for the Imaginary Unit and write z=(x,y) as z=x+\mathrm {i} y. (Electrical Engineers use j instead for the imaginary unit.)

fr:title.text: Properties of addition of complex numbers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of addition of complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.2.4
Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1},z_{2},z_{3}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Commutativity: z_{1}+z_{2}=z_{2}+z_{1}
Additive identity: There is a unique complex number denoted 0 such that for any z\in \mathbb {C} we have 0+z=z. Moreover, 0=(0,0).
Additive inverse: For each z\in \mathbb {C} there exists a unique complex number denoted -z such that z+(-z)=0. Moreover, if z=(x,y), then -z=(-x,-y).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Addition of complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics §2.2.1
Linear Algebra Done Right 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We define the Addition of complex numbers as the binary operator + by (a+\mathrm {i} b)+(c+\mathrm {i} d)=(a+c)+\mathrm {i}(b+d)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of multiplying complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.2.6
Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1},z_{2},z_{3}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Commutativity: z_{1}z_{2}=z_{2}z_{1}
Multiplicative identity: There is a unique complex number denoted 1 such that for any z\in \mathbb {C} we have 1z=z. Moreover, 1=(1,0).
Distributivity of multiplication over addition: z_{1}(z_{2}+z_{3})=z_{1}z_{2}+z_{1}z_{3}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Multiplicative inverse of complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.2.6
Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 1.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For any nonzero z\in \mathbb {C}, z\neq 0, there exists a unique complex number denoted z^{-1} such that zz^{-1}=1. Moreover, if z=x+\mathrm {i} y with x,y\in \mathbb {R}, then z^{-1}=\frac {x}{x^{2}+y^{2}}+\mathrm {i}\frac {-y}{x^{2}+y^{2}}
Uniqueness: Suppose there are two complex numbers w\in \mathbb {C} and v\in \mathbb {C} such that zv=1 and zw=1. Then v=1v=(zw)v=(wz)v=w(zv)=w1=w.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Complex conjugation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 2.2.8
Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 4.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z=x+\mathrm {i} y\in \mathbb {C} be a complex number with x,y\in \mathbb {R}. Then we define the Complex Conjugate of z to be the complex number \overline {z}=x-\mathrm {i} y.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of complex conjugation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.2.9
Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 4.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1} and z_{2}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: \overline {z_{1}+z_{2}}=\overline {z_{1}}+\overline {z_{2}} (the conjugate of the sum is the sum of conjugates)
\overline {z_{1}z_{2}}=\overline {z_{1}}\overline {z_{2}} (the conjugate of products is the product of conjugates)
\overline {1/z_{1}}=1/\overline {z_{1}} when z_{1}\neq 0
\overline {z_{1}}=z_{1} if and only if \Im (z_{1})=0
\Re (z_{1})=\frac {1}{2}(z_{1}+\overline {z_{1}}) and \Im (z_{1})=\frac {1}{2\mathrm {i}}(z_{1}-\overline {z_{1}}).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Modulus of complex number
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 2.2.10
Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 4.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z=x+\mathrm {i} y be a complex number with x,y\in \mathbb {R}. We define the Modulus of z to be the value |z|=\sqrt {x^{2}+y^{2}}>0. In particular, if x\in \mathbb {R}, then |x+\mathrm {i} 0|=\sqrt {x^{2}+0}=|x| is just the absolute value.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of modulus
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.2.11
Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 4.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1},z_{2}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Triangle inequality: |z_{1}+z_{2}|\leq |z_{1}|+|z_{2}|
z_{1}\overline {z_{1}}=|z_{1}|^{2} which implies when z_{1}\neq 0, z_{1}^{-1}=\frac {\overline {z_{1}}}{|z_{1}|^{2}}

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Polar form for complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics 2.3.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z=x+\mathrm {i} y be a complex number where x,y\in \mathbb {R}. Then we define the Argument of z to be the number \theta =\Arg (z) where 0\leq \theta <2\pi such that x=|z|\cos (\theta ) and y=|z|\sin (\theta ).
We can also write this in exponential form as z=|z|\exp (\mathrm {i}\theta ).

fr:title.text: Multiplication of complex numbers in exponential form

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Multiplication of complex numbers in exponential form
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 2.3.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1}=r_{1}\mathrm {e}^{\mathrm {i}\theta _{1}}, z_{2}=r_{2}\mathrm {e}^{\mathrm {i}\theta _{2}}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers in exponential form. Then z_{1}z_{2}=r_{1}r_{2}\mathrm {e}^{\mathrm {i}(\theta _{1}+\theta _{2})}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: De Moivre's formula
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.3.3
Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 4.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z=r(\cos (\theta )+\mathrm {i}\sin (\theta )) be a complex number in polar form. Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then:

fr:ol.fr:li: The exponentiation z^{n}=r^{n}(\cos (n\theta )+\mathrm {i}\sin (n\theta ));
The n^{\text {th}} roots of z are given by the n complex numbers z_{k}=r^{1/n}[\cos ((\theta +2\pi k)/n)+\mathrm {i}\sin ((\theta +2\pi k)/n)].

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Root of unity
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 2.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N}. We define the n^{\text {th}} Root of Unity to be 1^{1/n}=\cos (2\pi k/n)+\mathrm {i}\sin (2\pi k/n) where k=1,…,n.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Complex exponential
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 2.3.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z=x+\mathrm {i} y be a complex number with x,y\in \mathbb {R}. Then we define the Complex Exponential to be a function \exp \colon \mathbb {C}\to \mathbb {C} defined by \exp (z)=\mathrm {e}^{x}\mathrm {e}^{\mathrm {i} y}=\mathrm {e}^{x}(\cos (y)+\mathrm {i}\sin (y))

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Complex sine and cosine
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 2.3.4

fr:title.text: Properties of complex exponential and trigonometric functions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of complex exponential and trigonometric functions
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.3.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1},z_{2}\in \mathbb {C}. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: \mathrm {e}^{z_{1}+z_{2}}=\mathrm {e}^{z_{1}}\mathrm {e}^{z_{2}} and \mathrm {e}^{z}\neq 0 for any z\in \mathbb {C}

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Composing relations
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7
MML relat_1:def 8

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let P and R be relations. We define their Composition to be the relation denoted PR or R\circ P such that for all objects x and z we have (x,z)\in PR iff there exists an object y such that (x,y)\in P and (y,z)\in R.
The PR notation means xPRz iff there exists a y such that xPyRz.
The R\circ P notation is useful for working with functions.
Let f\colon W\to X, g\colon X\to Y, h\colon Y\to Z be functions. Then h\circ (g\circ f)=(h\circ g)\circ f.
This follows from composing relations is associative.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Composing relations is associative
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML relat_1:th36

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R_{1}, R_{2}, R_{3} be relations. Then (R_{1}\circ R_{2})\circ R_{3}=R_{1}\circ (R_{2}\circ R_{3}).

fr:title.text: Composition of linear transformations is a linear transformation

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Composition of linear transformations is a linear transformation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 3.7
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 6.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U, V, W be vector spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let S\in \mathcal {L}(U,V) and T\in \mathcal {L}(V,W) be linear maps. Then T\circ S\in \mathcal {L}(U,W) is a linear transformation defined by (T\circ S)(u)=T(S(u)) for all u\in U.

fr:title.text: Criteria for subset to be a subspace

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for subset to be a subspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.34
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 4.3.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let U\subseteq V be a subset. Then U is a subspace of V if the following conditions all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Additive identity: \vec {0}\in U
Closed under addition: for any u,v\in U, u+v\in U
Closed under scalar multiplication: for any a\in \mathbb {F} and u\in U, we have au\in U

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criterion for direct sum
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.45
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.4.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U_{1},U_{2}\subseteq V. Then U_{1}+U_{2} is a direct sum if and only if the only way we can write \vec {0}=u_{1}+u_{2} with u_{1}\in U_{1} and u_{2}\in U_{2} is for u_{1}=u_{2}=\vec {0}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Dimension
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 2.35
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 5.4.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let B be a basis of V. Then the Dimension of V is \dim (V) equal to the cardinality of B. In particular, if V is infinite-dimensional, we just write \dim (V)=\infty .
Compare this to the notion from elementary linear algebra.

fr:title.text: Dimension does not depend on choice of basis

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Dimension does not depend on choice of basis
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 2.34
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 5.4.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional vector space. Then every basis B of V has \dim (V)=|B|. In other words, the dimension of a finite-dimensional vector space is well-defined.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Dimension of a sum
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorems 2.43
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 5.4.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional vector space. Let U\subseteq V and W\subseteq V be subspaces. Then \dim (U+W)=\dim (U)+\dim (W)-\dim (U\cap W)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct image of a function
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.10

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. Let A\subseteq X. We define the Direct Image of A under f to be the set f(A)=\{f(x)\in Y\mid x\in A\}.
We sometimes use the notation f_{*}(A) for the direct image of A under f, so we can describe a function f_{*}\colon \mathcal {P}(X)\to \mathcal {P}(Y).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct image preserves only union
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Nicolas Bourbaki Theory of Sets R§2.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon X\to Y be a function, let L\subseteq X and R\subseteq X be subsets. Then the following all hold:

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum of spaces
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 1.36
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 4.4.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U_{1},U_{2}\subseteq V be subspaces of a vector space. We call U_{1}+U_{2} the Direct Sum if each element of U_{1}+U_{2} can be written in only one way as a sum u_{1}+u_{2} where u_{1}\in U_{1} and u_{2}\in U_{2}.
In this case, we write U_{1}\oplus U_{2}.

fr:title.text: Direct sum of two subspaces intersect in the zero subspace

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum of two subspaces intersect in the zero subspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.46
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.4.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U_{1},U_{2}\subseteq V be subspaces. Then U_{1}+U_{2} is a direct sum if and only if U_{1}\cap U_{2}=\{\vec {0}\}.

fr:title.text: Direct sum as Cartesian product of underlying sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum as Cartesian product of underlying sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If we are just given any two vector spaces V_{1} and V_{2} over the same field \mathbb {F}, then we can still form the direct sum of these spaces. We just take V_{1}\oplus V_{2}=\{(v_{1},v_{2})\mid v_{1}\in V_{1},v_{2}\in V_{2}\} and the operations are defined componentwise.
This is known as the External Direct Sum, but it is not taught usually to undergraduates.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Domain of a relation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a relation. We define the Domain of R to be the set \mathop {\mathrm {dom}}\nolimits (R)=\{x\mid \exists y\ldotp (x,y)\in R\}.
When R is a relation of X and Y, we see \mathop {\mathrm {dom}}\nolimits (R)\subseteq X.
Let X be a set. We say X is Empty if there is no object x such that x\in X.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equivalence relation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7
MML eqrel_1:def

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set. We define an Equivalence Relation of X to be a reflexive symmetric transitive relation of X.
For example, R=\{(x,x)\mid x\in X\} is always an equivalence relation of X which describes equality of elements of X.
More generally, an equivalence relation is a generalization of equality. Consequently, it is common to use notation like \sim , \approx , \equiv , \cong for equivalence relations.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equivalence class
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7
MML eqrel_1:def

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set, let x\in X, and let R be an equivalence relation of X. We define the Equivalence Class of x with respect to R is the set [x]_{R}=\{y\in X\mid (x,y)\in R\} consisting of all elements equivalent to x under R.
We have some very common sets encountered in Mathematics, so we have special notation for them:

fr:ul.fr:li: \mathbb {N}_{0}=\{0,1,2,3,…\} the set of all non-negative integers
\mathbb {N}=\{1,2,3,4,…\} the set of all positive integers
\mathbb {Z}=\{…,-3,-2,-1,0,1,2,3,…\} the set of all integers
\mathbb {Q}=\{\frac {m}{n}\mid m\in \mathbb {Z},n\in \mathbb {N} the set of all rational numbers
\mathbb {R} the set of real numbers
\mathbb {C}=\{x+\mathrm {i} y\mid x,y\in \mathbb {R}\} the set of complex numbers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence of basis
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 2.31
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Corollary 5.3.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Every finite-dimensional vector space has a basis.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence of complement of subspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 5.4.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional vector space, let U\subseteq V be a subspace. Then there exists a subspace W\subseteq V such that V=U\oplus W.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Extreme value theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 3.1.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon D\to \mathbb {R} be a continuous function on the closed disc D_{R}=\{(x_{1},x_{2})\in \mathbb {R}^{2}\mid x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}\leq R^{2}\} of radius R. Then f is bounded and attains its minimum and maximum values on D. In other words, there exists points x_{\text {min}},x_{\text {max}}\in D such that for all x\in D we have f(x_{\text {min}})\leq f(x)\leq f(x_{\text {max}})

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field of a relation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7
MML relat_1:def 6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a relation. We define the Field of R is just \mathop {\mathrm {dom}}\nolimits (R)\cup \mathop {\mathrm {ran}}\nolimits (R).
Observe when R is a relation of X and Y, the field F of R is a subset F\subseteq X\cup Y.

fr:title.text: Field-valued functions form a vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field-valued functions form a vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Example 1.25
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.1.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let D\neq \emptyset be any set. Let \mathbb {F} be a field. Then the Set of all functions \mathbb {F}^{D} forms a vector space. Vector addition of f,g\in \mathbb {F}^{D} is given by (f+g)(x)=f(x)+g(x) for any x\in D, and scalar multiplication is given by (af)(x)=af(x) for any a\in \mathbb {F}.

There are various related vector spaces of interest to Mathematicians. For example, when \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {R} and D\subseteq \mathbb {R}, the set of all continuous real-valued functions on D forms a subspace of \mathbb {R}^{D}.
If we have a set consisting of finitely many elements, we write it out as a comma-separated list delimited by \{…\}.
For example, the set of prime numbers less than 10 is \{2,3,5,7\}.

fr:title.text: Finite tuples over a field form a vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finite tuples over a field form a vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.1.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Consider \mathbb {F}^{n} the set of all n-tuples with values in \mathbb {F}. This is a vector space with addition and multiplication defined by (u_{1},…,u_{n})+(v_{1},…,v_{n})=(u_{1}+v_{1},…,u_{n}+v_{n}) a(u_{1},…,u_{n})=(au_{1},…,au_{n}) Then this really is a vector space.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finite-Dimensional Vector Space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 2.9
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 5.1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space. If there exists a finite subset S\subseteq V such that \mathrm {span}(S)=V, then we say V is Finite-Dimensional.
If there is no such finite set spanning the entire space, then we say V is Infinite-Dimensional.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Function
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.8

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let X and Y be sets. We define a Function from X to Y to be a relation of X and Y denoted f\colon X\to Y such that:
Total: \mathop {\mathrm {dom}}\nolimits (f)=X, and
Function-like: for all objects x, y, z such that (x,y)\in f and (x,z)\in f, we have y=z. Instead of (x,y)\in f, we write f(x)=y.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 3.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer, let a_{0},…,a_{n}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers with a_{n}\neq 0. Then the polynomial equation a_{n}z^{n}+…+a_{1}z+a_{0}=0 has at least one solution in z\in \mathbb {C}.
(It seems like every field has its own proof of the fundamental theorem of algebra, so I will link them here:)

fr:ul.fr:li: Proof: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra via Extreme Value Theorem

fr:title.text: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra via Extreme Value Theorem

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra via Extreme Value Theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 3.1
Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 4.12

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: By Modulus of complex polynomial attains a minimum value, we see that |f| attains its minimum value. Let z_{0}\in \mathbb {C} be a point where the minimum is attained. We will show if f(z_{0})\neq 0, then z_{0} is not a minimum (which proves by contrapositive that the minimum of |f(z)| is zero, and therefore f(z_{0})=0).

Let b\in \mathbb {C} be such that b^{k}=-1/a_{k}. There exists a constant c>1 such that if 0<t<1, then |g(tb)|\leq |1+a_{k}t^{k}b^{k}|+t^{k+1}c=1-t^{k}(1-tc) Taking t=1/(2c) in this inequality, we have |g(tb)|<1. But this contradicts the assumption that the minimum of |g(z)| is |g(0)|=1. This contradiction implies the result.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Extreme value theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 3.1.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon D\to \mathbb {R} be a continuous function on the closed disc D_{R}=\{(x_{1},x_{2})\in \mathbb {R}^{2}\mid x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}\leq R^{2}\} of radius R. Then f is bounded and attains its minimum and maximum values on D. In other words, there exists points x_{\text {min}},x_{\text {max}}\in D such that for all x\in D we have f(x_{\text {min}})\leq f(x)\leq f(x_{\text {max}})

fr:title.text: Modulus of complex polynomial attains a minimum value

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Modulus of complex polynomial attains a minimum value
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 3.1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon \mathbb {C}\to \mathbb {C} be a polynomial function. Then there exists a z_{0}\in \mathbb {C} where |f| attains its minimum value in \mathbb {R}.
Case 1: f is a constant polynomial. Then |f| attains its minimum value at every point in \mathbb {C}, so pick z_{0}=0 and we're done.

Case 2: f is not a constant polynomial. Then we can write it out as f(z)=a_{n}z^{n}+…+a_{1}z+a_{0} where n=\deg (f) is the degree of f, with a_{n}\neq 0. Set A=\max \{|a_{0}|,…,|a_{n}|\} Then we have A/|a_{n}|\geq 1, so |f(z)|\geq |a_{n}||z|^{n}\left (1-\frac {A}{|a_{n}|}\sum ^{\infty }_{k=1}\frac {1}{|z|^{k}}\right )=|a_{n}||z|^{n}\left (1-\frac {A}{|a_{n}|}\frac {1}{|z|-1}\right ) For all z\in \mathbb {C} such that |z|\geq 2, we can simplify this lower bound as |f(z)|\geq |a_{n}||z|^{n}\left (1-\frac {2A}{|a_{n}||z|}\right ) This implies there exists an R>0 such that |f(z)|>|f(0)| for all z\in \mathbb {C} such that |z|>R. Let D\subseteq \mathbb {R}^{2} be the close disk of radius R centered at the origin, then define g\colon D\to \mathbb {R} by g(x,y)=|f(x+\mathrm {i} y)|. Since g is continuous, we apply Extreme value theorem to obtain a point (x_{0},y_{0})\in D such that g attains a minimum at (x_{0},y_{0}). By the choice of R we have that for z\in \mathbb {C}\setminus D, |f(z)|>|g(0,0)|\geq |g(x_{0},y_{0})|. Therefore |f| attains its minimum at z=x_{0}+\mathrm {i} y_{0}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 3.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer, let a_{0},…,a_{n}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers with a_{n}\neq 0. Then the polynomial equation a_{n}z^{n}+…+a_{1}z+a_{0}=0 has at least one solution in z\in \mathbb {C}.
(It seems like every field has its own proof of the fundamental theorem of algebra, so I will link them here:)

fr:ul.fr:li: Proof: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra via Extreme Value Theorem

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Terminology surrounding polynomials
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 3.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If n=a_{0}=0, then we call p(z)=0 the Zero Polynomial. Convention dictates \deg (0)=-\infty .
We also call:

fr:ul.fr:li: degree zero polnomials are called constant polynomials
degree one polnomials are called linear polynomials
degree two polnomials are called quadratic polynomials
degree three polnomials are called cubic polynomials
degree four polnomials are called quartic polynomials
degree five polnomials are called quintic polynomials
… and so on.

fr:title.text: Properties of degrees of polynomials under arithmetic

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of degrees of polynomials under arithmetic
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 3.2.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let p(z) and q(z) be nonzero polynomials. Then:

fr:ol.fr:li: \deg (p(z)\pm q(z))\leq \max (\deg (p(z)),\deg (q(z))), and

fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 3.2.2

fr:ol.fr:li: For any w\in \mathbb {C}, we have f(w)=0 if there exists a polynomial g\colon \mathbb {C}\to \mathbb {C} of degree \deg (g)=n-1 such that f(z)=(z-w)g(z);
There are at most n distinct complex numbers w\in \mathbb {C} for which f(w)=0; i.e., f has at most n distinct roots;

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity function
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML relat_1:def 10

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set. We define the Identity Function of X to be the function \mathop {\mathrm {id}}\nolimits _{X}\colon X\to X such that for all x\in X, \mathop {\mathrm {id}}\nolimits _{X}(x)=x.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inclusion
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.8
MML funct_3:def

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a subset of Y. Then the Inclusion of X into Y is the function i\colon X\to Y defined by i(x)=x for all x\in X.

fr:title.text: Injective functions have a left inverse function

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Injective functions have a left inverse function

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon X\to Y be an Injective function. Then there exists a function g\colon Y\to X such that g\circ f=\mathop {\mathrm {id}}\nolimits _{X}.
We call such a g a Left Inverse of f.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Set of complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics §2.1
Linear Algebra Done Right 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We define the Set of Complex Numbers \mathbb {C}=\{(x,y)\mid x,y\in \mathbb {R}\}. Given a complex number z=(x,y), we call \Re (z)=x the Real Part of z, and \Im (z)=y the Imaginary Part of z.
We write \mathrm {i}=(0,1) for the Imaginary Unit and write z=(x,y) as z=x+\mathrm {i} y. (Electrical Engineers use j instead for the imaginary unit.)

fr:title.text: Properties of addition of complex numbers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of addition of complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.2.4
Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1},z_{2},z_{3}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Commutativity: z_{1}+z_{2}=z_{2}+z_{1}
Additive identity: There is a unique complex number denoted 0 such that for any z\in \mathbb {C} we have 0+z=z. Moreover, 0=(0,0).
Additive inverse: For each z\in \mathbb {C} there exists a unique complex number denoted -z such that z+(-z)=0. Moreover, if z=(x,y), then -z=(-x,-y).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Addition of complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics §2.2.1
Linear Algebra Done Right 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We define the Addition of complex numbers as the binary operator + by (a+\mathrm {i} b)+(c+\mathrm {i} d)=(a+c)+\mathrm {i}(b+d)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of multiplying complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.2.6
Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1},z_{2},z_{3}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Commutativity: z_{1}z_{2}=z_{2}z_{1}
Multiplicative identity: There is a unique complex number denoted 1 such that for any z\in \mathbb {C} we have 1z=z. Moreover, 1=(1,0).
Distributivity of multiplication over addition: z_{1}(z_{2}+z_{3})=z_{1}z_{2}+z_{1}z_{3}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Multiplicative inverse of complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.2.6
Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 1.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For any nonzero z\in \mathbb {C}, z\neq 0, there exists a unique complex number denoted z^{-1} such that zz^{-1}=1. Moreover, if z=x+\mathrm {i} y with x,y\in \mathbb {R}, then z^{-1}=\frac {x}{x^{2}+y^{2}}+\mathrm {i}\frac {-y}{x^{2}+y^{2}}
Uniqueness: Suppose there are two complex numbers w\in \mathbb {C} and v\in \mathbb {C} such that zv=1 and zw=1. Then v=1v=(zw)v=(wz)v=w(zv)=w1=w.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Complex conjugation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 2.2.8
Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 4.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z=x+\mathrm {i} y\in \mathbb {C} be a complex number with x,y\in \mathbb {R}. Then we define the Complex Conjugate of z to be the complex number \overline {z}=x-\mathrm {i} y.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of complex conjugation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.2.9
Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 4.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1} and z_{2}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: \overline {z_{1}+z_{2}}=\overline {z_{1}}+\overline {z_{2}} (the conjugate of the sum is the sum of conjugates)
\overline {z_{1}z_{2}}=\overline {z_{1}}\overline {z_{2}} (the conjugate of products is the product of conjugates)
\overline {1/z_{1}}=1/\overline {z_{1}} when z_{1}\neq 0
\overline {z_{1}}=z_{1} if and only if \Im (z_{1})=0
\Re (z_{1})=\frac {1}{2}(z_{1}+\overline {z_{1}}) and \Im (z_{1})=\frac {1}{2\mathrm {i}}(z_{1}-\overline {z_{1}}).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Modulus of complex number
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 2.2.10
Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 4.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z=x+\mathrm {i} y be a complex number with x,y\in \mathbb {R}. We define the Modulus of z to be the value |z|=\sqrt {x^{2}+y^{2}}>0. In particular, if x\in \mathbb {R}, then |x+\mathrm {i} 0|=\sqrt {x^{2}+0}=|x| is just the absolute value.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of modulus
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.2.11
Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 4.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1},z_{2}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Triangle inequality: |z_{1}+z_{2}|\leq |z_{1}|+|z_{2}|
z_{1}\overline {z_{1}}=|z_{1}|^{2} which implies when z_{1}\neq 0, z_{1}^{-1}=\frac {\overline {z_{1}}}{|z_{1}|^{2}}

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Polar form for complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics 2.3.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z=x+\mathrm {i} y be a complex number where x,y\in \mathbb {R}. Then we define the Argument of z to be the number \theta =\Arg (z) where 0\leq \theta <2\pi such that x=|z|\cos (\theta ) and y=|z|\sin (\theta ).
We can also write this in exponential form as z=|z|\exp (\mathrm {i}\theta ).

fr:title.text: Multiplication of complex numbers in exponential form

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Multiplication of complex numbers in exponential form
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 2.3.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1}=r_{1}\mathrm {e}^{\mathrm {i}\theta _{1}}, z_{2}=r_{2}\mathrm {e}^{\mathrm {i}\theta _{2}}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers in exponential form. Then z_{1}z_{2}=r_{1}r_{2}\mathrm {e}^{\mathrm {i}(\theta _{1}+\theta _{2})}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: De Moivre's formula
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.3.3
Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 4.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z=r(\cos (\theta )+\mathrm {i}\sin (\theta )) be a complex number in polar form. Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then:

fr:ol.fr:li: The exponentiation z^{n}=r^{n}(\cos (n\theta )+\mathrm {i}\sin (n\theta ));
The n^{\text {th}} roots of z are given by the n complex numbers z_{k}=r^{1/n}[\cos ((\theta +2\pi k)/n)+\mathrm {i}\sin ((\theta +2\pi k)/n)].

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Root of unity
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 2.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N}. We define the n^{\text {th}} Root of Unity to be 1^{1/n}=\cos (2\pi k/n)+\mathrm {i}\sin (2\pi k/n) where k=1,…,n.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Complex exponential
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 2.3.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z=x+\mathrm {i} y be a complex number with x,y\in \mathbb {R}. Then we define the Complex Exponential to be a function \exp \colon \mathbb {C}\to \mathbb {C} defined by \exp (z)=\mathrm {e}^{x}\mathrm {e}^{\mathrm {i} y}=\mathrm {e}^{x}(\cos (y)+\mathrm {i}\sin (y))

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Complex sine and cosine
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 2.3.4

fr:title.text: Properties of complex exponential and trigonometric functions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of complex exponential and trigonometric functions
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.3.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1},z_{2}\in \mathbb {C}. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: \mathrm {e}^{z_{1}+z_{2}}=\mathrm {e}^{z_{1}}\mathrm {e}^{z_{2}} and \mathrm {e}^{z}\neq 0 for any z\in \mathbb {C}

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Extreme value theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 3.1.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon D\to \mathbb {R} be a continuous function on the closed disc D_{R}=\{(x_{1},x_{2})\in \mathbb {R}^{2}\mid x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}\leq R^{2}\} of radius R. Then f is bounded and attains its minimum and maximum values on D. In other words, there exists points x_{\text {min}},x_{\text {max}}\in D such that for all x\in D we have f(x_{\text {min}})\leq f(x)\leq f(x_{\text {max}})

fr:title.text: Modulus of complex polynomial attains a minimum value

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Modulus of complex polynomial attains a minimum value
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 3.1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon \mathbb {C}\to \mathbb {C} be a polynomial function. Then there exists a z_{0}\in \mathbb {C} where |f| attains its minimum value in \mathbb {R}.
Case 1: f is a constant polynomial. Then |f| attains its minimum value at every point in \mathbb {C}, so pick z_{0}=0 and we're done.

Case 2: f is not a constant polynomial. Then we can write it out as f(z)=a_{n}z^{n}+…+a_{1}z+a_{0} where n=\deg (f) is the degree of f, with a_{n}\neq 0. Set A=\max \{|a_{0}|,…,|a_{n}|\} Then we have A/|a_{n}|\geq 1, so |f(z)|\geq |a_{n}||z|^{n}\left (1-\frac {A}{|a_{n}|}\sum ^{\infty }_{k=1}\frac {1}{|z|^{k}}\right )=|a_{n}||z|^{n}\left (1-\frac {A}{|a_{n}|}\frac {1}{|z|-1}\right ) For all z\in \mathbb {C} such that |z|\geq 2, we can simplify this lower bound as |f(z)|\geq |a_{n}||z|^{n}\left (1-\frac {2A}{|a_{n}||z|}\right ) This implies there exists an R>0 such that |f(z)|>|f(0)| for all z\in \mathbb {C} such that |z|>R. Let D\subseteq \mathbb {R}^{2} be the close disk of radius R centered at the origin, then define g\colon D\to \mathbb {R} by g(x,y)=|f(x+\mathrm {i} y)|. Since g is continuous, we apply Extreme value theorem to obtain a point (x_{0},y_{0})\in D such that g attains a minimum at (x_{0},y_{0}). By the choice of R we have that for z\in \mathbb {C}\setminus D, |f(z)|>|g(0,0)|\geq |g(x_{0},y_{0})|. Therefore |f| attains its minimum at z=x_{0}+\mathrm {i} y_{0}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 3.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer, let a_{0},…,a_{n}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers with a_{n}\neq 0. Then the polynomial equation a_{n}z^{n}+…+a_{1}z+a_{0}=0 has at least one solution in z\in \mathbb {C}.
(It seems like every field has its own proof of the fundamental theorem of algebra, so I will link them here:)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Terminology surrounding polynomials
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 3.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If n=a_{0}=0, then we call p(z)=0 the Zero Polynomial. Convention dictates \deg (0)=-\infty .
We also call:

fr:ul.fr:li: degree zero polnomials are called constant polynomials
degree one polnomials are called linear polynomials
degree two polnomials are called quadratic polynomials
degree three polnomials are called cubic polynomials
degree four polnomials are called quartic polynomials
degree five polnomials are called quintic polynomials
… and so on.

fr:title.text: Properties of degrees of polynomials under arithmetic

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of degrees of polynomials under arithmetic
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 3.2.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let p(z) and q(z) be nonzero polynomials. Then:

fr:ol.fr:li: \deg (p(z)\pm q(z))\leq \max (\deg (p(z)),\deg (q(z))), and

fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 3.2.2

fr:ol.fr:li: For any w\in \mathbb {C}, we have f(w)=0 if there exists a polynomial g\colon \mathbb {C}\to \mathbb {C} of degree \deg (g)=n-1 such that f(z)=(z-w)g(z);
There are at most n distinct complex numbers w\in \mathbb {C} for which f(w)=0; i.e., f has at most n distinct roots;

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Field is traditionally defined as a set F with two binary operators, addition (denoted +) and multiplication (denoted \cdot ), satisfying the field axioms:

fr:ol.fr:li: Associativity of addition: for all x,y,z\in F, (x+y)+z=x+(y+z)
Commutativity of addition: for all x,y\in F, x+y=y+x
Additive identity: there exists a 0\in F such that for all x\in F we have 0+x=x and x+0=x
Additive inverses: for each x\in F there is a unique y\in F such that x+y=0 and y+x=0; in this case, we usually denote y as (-x)
Associativity of multiplication: for all x,y,z\in F, (x\cdot y)\cdot z=x\cdot (y\cdot z)
Commutativity of multiplication: for all x,y\in F, x\cdot y=y\cdot x
Multiplicative identity: there exists a 1\in F such that for all x\in F we have 1\cdot x=x and x\cdot 1=x
Multiplicative inverses: for each x\in F which is nonzero x\neq 0 there is a unique y\in F such that x\cdot y=1 and y\cdot x=1; usually we denote y as x^{-1}
Distributivity of multiplication over addition: for all x,y,z\in F, we have x\cdot (y+z)=(x\cdot y)+(x\cdot z) and (x+y)\cdot z=(x\cdot z)+(x\cdot y)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Note that some of these are redundant.
Also note: fields are usually written in blackboard bold, and the generic field is either \mathbb {F} or \Bbbk (since the German word for field is "Körper").

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Vector Space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 1.20
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 4.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field. A Vector Space over \mathbb {F} consists of a set V equipped with vector addition +\colon V\times V\to V and scalar multiplication \cdot \colon \mathbb {F}\times V\to V such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: Commutativity: for all u,v\in V, we have u+v=v+u
Associativity: for all u,v,w\in V, we have (u+v)+w=u+(v+w)
Additive identity: there exists a \vec {0}\in V such that for all v\in V we have v+\vec {0}=v
Additive inverse: for each v\in V there exists a w\in V such that v+w=\vec {0}
Associativity of scalar multiplication: for all v\in V and a,b\in \mathbb {F}, we have (ab)v=a(bv)
Multiplicative identity: The multiplicative unital element 1\in \mathbb {F} is such that for all v\in V we have 1v=v
Distributivity: for all a,b\in \mathbb {F} and u,v\in V we have a(u+v)=au+av and (a+b)v=av+bv

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Compare this to the definition of a Real vector space from elementary linear algebra. When \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {R}, we call V a real vector space. When \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {C}, we call V a Complex Vector Space.

fr:title.text: Finite tuples over a field form a vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finite tuples over a field form a vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.1.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Consider \mathbb {F}^{n} the set of all n-tuples with values in \mathbb {F}. This is a vector space with addition and multiplication defined by (u_{1},…,u_{n})+(v_{1},…,v_{n})=(u_{1}+v_{1},…,u_{n}+v_{n}) a(u_{1},…,u_{n})=(au_{1},…,au_{n}) Then this really is a vector space.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Vector space of sequences
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Example 1.23
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field. Then \mathbb {F}^{\infty } is the set of all sequences over \mathbb {F}. Then vector addition defined componentwise (u_{k})+(v_{k})=(u_{k}+v_{k}) and scalar multiplication defined componentwise a(u_{n})=(au_{n}) give us a vector space.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Polynomials form a vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Example 1.23
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.1.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F}[z] be the set of all polynomial with coefficients in \mathbb {F} and in unknown z. Then defining (p+q)(z)=p(z)+q(z) and (ap)(z)=ap(z) for any a\in \mathbb {F} and p,q\in \mathbb {F}[z] forms vector addition and scalar multiplication.

fr:title.text: Field-valued functions form a vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field-valued functions form a vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Example 1.25
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.1.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let D\neq \emptyset be any set. Let \mathbb {F} be a field. Then the Set of all functions \mathbb {F}^{D} forms a vector space. Vector addition of f,g\in \mathbb {F}^{D} is given by (f+g)(x)=f(x)+g(x) for any x\in D, and scalar multiplication is given by (af)(x)=af(x) for any a\in \mathbb {F}.

There are various related vector spaces of interest to Mathematicians. For example, when \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {R} and D\subseteq \mathbb {R}, the set of all continuous real-valued functions on D forms a subspace of \mathbb {R}^{D}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Zero vector is unique
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.26
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Then the additive identity \vec {0}\in V is unique.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Additive inverse is unique
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.27
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. For each v\in V, there is a unique additive inverse of v in V.
Suppose w and w' are additive inverses of v. Then w=w+0=w+(v+w')=(w+v)+w'=0+w'=w' which gives us w=w' as desired.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Additive inverse and vector subtraction
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Notation 1.28

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. We denote by -v the additive inverse of v\in V.
Similarly, for any v,w\in V, we denote by v-w the expression v+(-w).

fr:title.text: Scalar multiplication by zero gives zero vector

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Scalar multiplication by zero gives zero vector
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.30
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let v\in V and 0_{F}\in \mathbb {F}. Then 0_{F}v=\vec {0}.
We see by distributivity, 0_{F}v=(0_{F}+0_{F})v=0_{F}v+0_{F}v, and then subtracting 0_{F}v from both sides yields \vec {0}=0_{F}v-0_{F}v=(0_{F}v+0_{F}v)-0_{F}v=0_{F}v as desired.

fr:title.text: Scalar multiples of zero vector are the zero vector

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Scalar multiples of zero vector are the zero vector
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.31
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let \vec {0}\in V and a\in \mathbb {F}. Then a\vec {0}=\vec {0}.
We see a\vec {0}=a(\vec {0}+\vec {0})=a\vec {0}+a\vec {0}, then adding the additive inverse of a\vec {0} to both sides yields the result.

fr:title.text: Negating a vector by multiplying by minus one

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Negating a vector by multiplying by minus one
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.32
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let v\in V. Then (-1)v=-v.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 1.33
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 4.3.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let U\subseteq V be a subset. Then we call U a Subspace of V if U is a vector space over \mathbb {F} under the same operations that make V a vector space over \mathbb {F}.
In particular, V is always a subspace of itself.
Compare this to Subspace of a real vector space from elementary linear algebra.

fr:title.text: Criteria for subset to be a subspace

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for subset to be a subspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.34
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 4.3.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let U\subseteq V be a subset. Then U is a subspace of V if the following conditions all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Additive identity: \vec {0}\in U
Closed under addition: for any u,v\in U, u+v\in U
Closed under scalar multiplication: for any a\in \mathbb {F} and u\in U, we have au\in U

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Trivial subspaces
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.3.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Then V is a subspace of V and also \{\vec {0}\} is a subspace of V. They are called the Trivial Subspaces of V.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sum of subspaces
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 1.36
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 4.4.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let U_{1},U_{2}\subseteq V be subspaces of V. We define the (Subspace) Sum of U_{1} and U_{2} to be the set U_{1}+U_{2}=\{u_{1}+u_{2}\mid u_{1}\in U_{1},u_{2}\in U_{2}\}.
More precisely, this is a subspace of V.
This can be extended to any finite number of subspaces of V.

fr:title.text: Sum of subspaces is smallest subspace containing the summands

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sum of subspaces is smallest subspace containing the summands
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.40

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U_{1},…,U_{m}\subseteq V be subspaces of a vector space V. Then U_{1}+…+U_{m} is the smallest subspace of V containing U_{1}, …, U_{n}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum of spaces
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 1.36
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 4.4.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U_{1},U_{2}\subseteq V be subspaces of a vector space. We call U_{1}+U_{2} the Direct Sum if each element of U_{1}+U_{2} can be written in only one way as a sum u_{1}+u_{2} where u_{1}\in U_{1} and u_{2}\in U_{2}.
In this case, we write U_{1}\oplus U_{2}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criterion for direct sum
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.45
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.4.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U_{1},U_{2}\subseteq V. Then U_{1}+U_{2} is a direct sum if and only if the only way we can write \vec {0}=u_{1}+u_{2} with u_{1}\in U_{1} and u_{2}\in U_{2} is for u_{1}=u_{2}=\vec {0}.

fr:title.text: Direct sum of two subspaces intersect in the zero subspace

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum of two subspaces intersect in the zero subspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 1.46
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.4.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U_{1},U_{2}\subseteq V be subspaces. Then U_{1}+U_{2} is a direct sum if and only if U_{1}\cap U_{2}=\{\vec {0}\}.

fr:title.text: Direct sum as Cartesian product of underlying sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum as Cartesian product of underlying sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If we are just given any two vector spaces V_{1} and V_{2} over the same field \mathbb {F}, then we can still form the direct sum of these spaces. We just take V_{1}\oplus V_{2}=\{(v_{1},v_{2})\mid v_{1}\in V_{1},v_{2}\in V_{2}\} and the operations are defined componentwise.
This is known as the External Direct Sum, but it is not taught usually to undergraduates.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear combination
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 2.2
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 5.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let v_{1},…,v_{n}\in V. Then we define a Linear Combination of v_{1}, …, v_{n} to be a_{1}v_{1}+…+a_{n}v_{n} for some a_{1},…,a_{n}\in \mathbb {F}.
Compare this to the notion of Linear combination from elementary linear algebra.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Span
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 2.4
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 5.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Compare this to the Span of a set of vectors from elementary linear algebra.

fr:title.text: Span is smallest subset containing the supplied vectors

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Span is smallest subset containing the supplied vectors
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 2.6
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 5.1.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}, let v_{1},…,v_{m}\in V be vectors. Then
v_{j}\in \mathrm {span}(v_{1},…,v_{m}) for each j, and
for any other subspace U\subseteq V such that v_{j}\in U for each j=1,…,m, we have \mathrm {span}(v_{1},…,v_{m})\subseteq U.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finite-Dimensional Vector Space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 2.9
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 5.1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space. If there exists a finite subset S\subseteq V such that \mathrm {span}(S)=V, then we say V is Finite-Dimensional.
If there is no such finite set spanning the entire space, then we say V is Infinite-Dimensional.

fr:title.text: Vector space of polynomials is infinite-dimensional

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Vector space of polynomials is infinite-dimensional
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Example 2.14
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 5.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field. Then the vector space of polynomials \mathbb {F}[z] is an infinite-dimensional vector space.

Let S\subseteq \mathbb {F}[z] be any finite set, let N=\{\deg (p)\mid p\in S\}. Then consider the smallest positive integer n\in \mathbb {N} which is not n\notin N. Then z^{n}\notin \mathrm {span}(S). So \mathbb {F}[z] cannot be finite-dimensional.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linearly Independent Vectors
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 2.15
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 5.2.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Otherwise, we say v_{1},…,v_{m}\in V are Linearly Dependent.
Compare this to the notion from elementary linear algebra.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear Dependence Lemma
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Lemma 2.19
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 5.2.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let v_{1},…,v_{m}\in V be linearly dependent. If v_{1}\neq 0, then there exists an index j\in \{2,…,m\} such that the following hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: If v_{j} is removed from \{v_{1},…,v_{m}\}, then \mathrm {span}(v_{1},…,\hat {v}_{j},…,v_{m})=\mathrm {span}(v_{1},…,v_{m})

fr:title.text: Length of linearly independent list not greater than length of spanning set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Length of linearly independent list not greater than length of spanning set
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 2.22
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 5.2.9

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional vector space. Suppose that v_{1},…,v_{m} are linearly independent vectors of V, and suppose S\subseteq V be a spanning set \mathrm {span}(S)=V. Then m\leq |S|.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Basis of vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 2.26
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 5.3.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let v_{1},…,v_{m}\in V be vectors. We say B=\{v_{1},…,v_{m}\} is a Basis of V if B is linearly independent and \mathrm {span}(B)=V.
Compare this to Basis of Vector Space from elementary linear algebra.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Basis reduction theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 2.30
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 5.3.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If V=\mathrm {span}(v_{1},…,v_{m}), then either \{v_{1},…,v_{m}\} forms a basis of V or some v_{i} can be removed to obtain a basis of V.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence of basis
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 2.31
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Corollary 5.3.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Every finite-dimensional vector space has a basis.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Basis extension theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 2.32
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 5.3.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Every linearly independent set in a finite-dimensional vector space V can be extended to a basis of V.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Dimension
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 2.35
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 5.4.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let B be a basis of V. Then the Dimension of V is \dim (V) equal to the cardinality of B. In particular, if V is infinite-dimensional, we just write \dim (V)=\infty .
Compare this to the notion from elementary linear algebra.

fr:title.text: Dimension does not depend on choice of basis

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Dimension does not depend on choice of basis
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 2.34
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 5.4.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional vector space. Then every basis B of V has \dim (V)=|B|. In other words, the dimension of a finite-dimensional vector space is well-defined.

fr:title.text: Properties of bases of finite-dimensional vector spaces and subspaces

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of bases of finite-dimensional vector spaces and subspaces
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorems 2.37, 2.38, 2.42
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 5.4.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional vector space with n=\dim (V). Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Every subspace U\subseteq V has \dim (U)\leq \dim (V).
If V=\mathrm {span}(v_{1},…,v_{n}), then \{v_{1},…,v_{n}\} is a basis of V.
If \{v_{1},…,v_{n}\} is linearly independent in V, then \{v_{1},…,v_{n}\} forms a basis of V.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence of complement of subspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 5.4.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional vector space, let U\subseteq V be a subspace. Then there exists a subspace W\subseteq V such that V=U\oplus W.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Dimension of a sum
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorems 2.43
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 5.4.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional vector space. Let U\subseteq V and W\subseteq V be subspaces. Then \dim (U+W)=\dim (U)+\dim (W)-\dim (U\cap W)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear map
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 3.1
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 6.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let V and W be vector spaces over \mathbb {F}. A Linear Map from V to W is a function L\colon V\to W such that:
Additive: L(u+v)=L(u)+L(v) for all u,v\in V, and
Homogeneous: L(av)=aL(v) for all a\in \mathbb {F} and v\in V We denote the set of all linear transformations from V to W by \mathcal {L}(V,W).

fr:title.text: Differentiation is a linear operator on space of polynomials

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Differentiation is a linear operator on space of polynomials

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let \mathbb {F}[z] be the vector space of polynomials with coefficients in \mathbb {F} and in unknown z. Then \frac {\mathrm {d}}{\mathrm {d} z}\colon \mathbb {F}[z]\to \mathbb {F}[z] defined by \frac {\mathrm {d}}{\mathrm {d} z}(a_{0}+a_{1}z+…+a_{n}z^{n})=a_{1}+…+a_{k}kz^{k-1}+…+a_{n}nz^{n-1} is a linear operator on \mathbb {F}[z].

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear map lemma
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Lemma 3.4
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 6.1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be finite-dimensional vector spaces over \mathbb {F}. Suppose v_{1},…,v_{n} is a basis of V, and suppose w_{1},…,w_{n} is a basis of W. Then there exists a unique linear map T\colon V\to W such that T(v_{i})=w_{i} for each i=1,…,n.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Addition of linear maps
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 3.5
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 6.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be vector spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let S,T\in \mathcal {L}(V,W) be linear transformations from V to W. Then we may define the Sum of S and T to be the linear transformation S+T defined by (S+T)(v)=S(v)+T(v) for all v\in V.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Scalar multiplication of linear maps
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 3.5
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 6.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be vector spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let S\in \mathcal {L}(V,W) be a linear transformation from V to W and a\in \mathbb {F}. Then we may define the Scalar multiple aS to be the linear transformation defined by (aS)(v)=aS(v) for all v\in V.

fr:title.text: Linear maps form a vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear maps form a vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 3.6
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 6.1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be vector spaces over \mathbb {F}. Then \mathcal {L}(V,W) forms a vector space over \mathbb {F}.

fr:title.text: Composition of linear transformations is a linear transformation

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Composition of linear transformations is a linear transformation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 3.7
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 6.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U, V, W be vector spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let S\in \mathcal {L}(U,V) and T\in \mathcal {L}(V,W) be linear maps. Then T\circ S\in \mathcal {L}(U,W) is a linear transformation defined by (T\circ S)(u)=T(S(u)) for all u\in U.

fr:title.text: Algebraic properties of composition of linear transformations

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Algebraic properties of composition of linear transformations
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 3.8
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 6.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The following hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Associativity: for any T_{1}\in \mathcal {L}(V_{1},V_{2}), T_{2}\in \mathcal {L}(V_{2},V_{3}), T_{3}\in \mathcal {L}(V_{3},V_{4}), we have (T_{1}\circ T_{2})\circ T_{3}=T_{1}\circ (T_{2}\circ T_{3}).
Identity: I\circ T=T and T\circ I=T for any T\in \mathcal {L}(V,W)
Distributivity: (S_{1}+S_{2})\circ T=(S_{1}\circ T)+(S_{2}\circ T) and S\circ (T_{1}+T_{2})=(S\circ T_{1})+(S\circ T_{2}) whenver these are defined.

fr:title.text: Linear maps take zero to zero

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear maps take zero to zero
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 3.10

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let L\colon V\to W be a linear map of vector spaces. Then L(\vec {0}_{V})=\vec {0}_{W}.
We see L(\vec {0}_{V})=L(\vec {0}_{V}+\vec {0}_{V})=L(\vec {0}_{V})+L(\vec {0}_{V}) and then adding the inverse of L(\vec {0}_{V}) gives the result.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Kernel of linear map
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 3.11
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 6.2.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let L\colon V\to W be a linear map. Then the Kernel (or "null space") of L is the set \ker (L) of all vectors of V mapped to the zero vector of W by L; i.e., \ker (L)=\{v\in V\mid L(v)=\vec {0}_{W}\}

fr:title.text: Kernel is a subspace of the domain

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Kernel is a subspace of the domain
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 3.13
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 6.2.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let L\colon V\to W be a linear map. Then \ker (L) is a subspace of V.
Claim 1: for any u,v\in \ker (L), we claim (u+v)\in \ker (L). Observe L(u+v)=L(u)+L(v)=\vec {0}_{W}+\vec {0}_{W}=\vec {0}_{W}, which implies (u+v)\in \ker (L) as desired.
Claim 2: For any a\in \mathbb {F} and v\in \ker (L), we see L(av)=aL(v)=a\vec {0}_{W}=\vec {0}_{W} by Scalar multiples of zero vector are the zero vector, hence av\in \ker (L).
From these two claims and by Criteria for subset to be a subspace, we have the result.
Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. We say f is injective (or that it's a injection) if for all x_{1},x_{2}\in X such that f(x_{1})=f(x_{2}) we have x_{1}=x_{2}.
Equivalently, if f(x_{1})\neq f(x_{2}), then x_{1}\neq x_{2}.
So no two distinct elements of X are mapped to the same element under f.

fr:title.text: Linear transformation is injective iff kernel is trivial

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear transformation is injective iff kernel is trivial
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 3.15
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 6.2.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let L\colon V\to W be a linear map. Then L is injective if and only if \ker (L)=\{\vec {0}\}.
Assume L is injective. We know \vec {0}\in \ker (L). Let v\in \ker (L) be arbitrary. Then L(v)=\vec {0}_{W}=L(\vec {0_{V}}) which implies v=\vec {0}_{V}. Hence \ker (L)=\{\vec {0}_{V}\} as desired.

Now, assume \ker (L)=\{\vec {0}\}. We will show that L is injective Let u,v\in V. Suppose L(u)=L(v). Then \vec {0}_{W}=L(u)-L(v)=L(u-v), so (u-v)\in \ker (L). But by assumption, this means (u-v)\in \{\vec {0}_{V}\}, which implies u-v=\vec {0}_{V}, which means (by adding v to both sides) u=v. Hence L is injective.
Let X and Y be sets, let f\colon X\to Y be a function. We define the Image (or Range) of f to be the subset \mathop {\mathrm {ran}}\nolimits (f)=f(X)=\{f(x)\in Y\mid x\in X\}.

fr:title.text: Image of linear map is a subspace of codomain

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Image of linear map is a subspace of codomain
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 3.18
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 6.2.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let L\colon V\to W be a linear map. Then its image \mathop {\mathrm {ran}}\nolimits (L) is a subspace of W.
Well, since Linear maps take zero to zero, we have established that L(\vec {0}_{V})=\vec {0}_{W}.

Let w\in \mathop {\mathrm {ran}}\nolimits (L) and a\in \mathbb {F}. Then there exists a v\in V such that L(v)=w. We see L(av)=aL(v)=aw which implies aw\in \mathop {\mathrm {ran}}\nolimits (L). Hence the result.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Dimensional formula
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 3.21
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 6.5.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let V be a Finite-Dimensional Vector Space over \mathbb {F}. Let W be a (not necessarily finite-dimensional) vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to W be a linear map. Then the following all hold:
\mathop {\mathrm {ran}}\nolimits (L) is a finite-dimensional subspace of W, and
\dim (V)=\dim (\ker (L))+\dim (\mathop {\mathrm {ran}}\nolimits (L))
Note: this theorem goes by many names (e.g., Axler calls it "the fundamental theorem of linear maps").

fr:title.text: Linear map to lower-dimensional space cannot be injective

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear map to lower-dimensional space cannot be injective
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 3.22
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Corollary 6.5.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be Finite-Dimensional Vector Spaces over \mathbb {F} such that \dim (V)>\dim (W). Then no linear map L\colon V\to W can be injective.

fr:title.text: Linear map to higher-dimensional spaces cannot be surjective

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear map to higher-dimensional spaces cannot be surjective
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 3.24
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Corollary 6.5.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be Finite-Dimensional Vector Spaces over \mathbb {F} such that \dim (V)<\dim (W). Then no linear map L\colon V\to W can be surjective.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Matrix of a linear map
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 3.31
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 6.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be Finite-Dimensional Vector Spaces over \mathbb {F}, let (e_{1},…,e_{n}) be an ordered basis of V, let (f_{1},…,f_{m}) be an ordered basis of W, let L\colon V\to W be a linear map.
Compare this to the notion in elementary linear algebra.

fr:title.text: Matrix of sum of linear maps

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Matrix of sum of linear maps
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 3.35
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 6.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be Finite-Dimensional Vector Spaces over \mathbb {F}, let L_{1},L_{2}\colon V\to W be linear maps.
Then the matrix of the sum of linear maps is the matrix sum of respective matrices M(L_{1}+L_{2})=M(L_{1})+M(L_{2}).

fr:title.text: Matrix of a scalar multiple of a linear map

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Matrix of a scalar multiple of a linear map
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 3.38
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 6.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be Finite-Dimensional Vector Spaces over \mathbb {F}, let L\colon V\to W be a linear map, let a\in \mathbb {F}.
Then the matrix of a scalar multiple of L is a scalar multiple of the matrix, i.e., M(aL)=aM(L).

fr:title.text: Matrix of composition of linear transformations is matrix multiplication

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Matrix of composition of linear transformations is matrix multiplication
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 3.43
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 6.6.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U, V, and W be Finite-Dimensional Vector Spaces over \mathbb {F}, let L_{1}\colon U\to V and L_{2}\colon V\to W be linear maps.
Then the matrix of their composition is the matrix multiplication of their respective matrices: M(L_{2}\circ L_{1})=M(L_{2})M(L_{1}).

Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. We call a function g\colon Y\to X the Inverse of f if f\circ g=\mathop {\mathrm {id}}\nolimits _{Y} and g\circ f=\mathop {\mathrm {id}}\nolimits _{X}. When such a g exists, we denote it by f^{-1}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Bijective functions have unique inverse
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML funct_1:def 5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon X\to Y be an Bijective function. Then there exists a function g\colon Y\to X such that f\circ g=\mathop {\mathrm {id}}\nolimits _{Y} and g\circ f=\mathop {\mathrm {id}}\nolimits _{X}. Moreover this function g is unique.
We call such a g the Inverse of f, and we usually denote it by f^{-1}=g.
We see that if (x,y)\in f, then (y,x)\in g.

fr:title.text: Inverse of a linear transformation is linear

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inverse of a linear transformation is linear
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 6.7.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be vector spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to W be invertible. Then L^{-1}\colon W\to V is a linear transformation.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Isomorphic vector spaces
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 3.69
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 6.7.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be vector spaces over \mathbb {F}. We say V and W are Isomorphic if there exists a bijective linear transformation L\colon V\to W. We will often write V\iso W to indicate V and W are isomorphic.
In this case, we often call L an Isomorphism.

fr:title.text: Finite-dimensional vector spaces are isomorphic iff they are the same dimension

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finite-dimensional vector spaces are isomorphic iff they are the same dimension
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 6.7.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be finite-dimension vector spaces over \mathbb {F}. Then V is isomorphic to W if and only if \dim (V)=\dim (W).

fr:title.text: Injective linear maps between finite-dimensional vector spaces are surjective

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Injective linear maps between finite-dimensional vector spaces are surjective
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 3.65
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 6.7.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let V and W be finite-dimensional vector spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to W. Then the following are equivalent:
L is invertible
L is surjective
L is injective

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Invariant subspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 5.2
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 7.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let L\in \mathcal {L}(V) be a linear operator on V. We call a subspace U\subseteq V Invariant under L if for each u\in U we have L(u)\in U.
That is to say, the image of every vector in U under L remains in U. So L(U)\subseteq U.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Eigenvalues and eigenvectors
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definitions 5.5 and 5.8
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 7.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator on V. Then \lambda \in \mathbb {F} is an Eigenvalue of L if there is a non-zero vector u\in V such that L(u)=\lambda u. The vector u is called an Eigenvector of L corresponding to eigenvalue \lambda .
Compare this to the notion in elementary linear algebra.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Eigenspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definition 5.2
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 7.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator on V. Then \lambda \in \mathbb {F} be an eigenvalue of L. Then we define the Eigenspace of L to be V_{\lambda }=\{v\in V\mid L(v)=\lambda v\}

fr:title.text: Equivalent conditions to be an eigenvalue

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equivalent conditions to be an eigenvalue
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 5.7
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 7.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator. Let \lambda \in \mathbb {F}. Then the following are equivalent:

fr:ol.fr:li: \lambda is an eigenvalue of L
L-\lambda I is not injective
L-\lambda I is not surjective
L-\lambda I is not invertible

fr:title.text: Eigenvectors of distinct eigenvalues are linearly independent

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Eigenvectors of distinct eigenvalues are linearly independent
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 5.11
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 7.2.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}, let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator. Let \lambda _{1},…,\lambda _{m}\in \mathbb {F} be distinct eigenvalues of L with corresponding nonzero eigenvectors v_{1},…,v_{m}\in V. Then v_{1},…,v_{m} are linearly independent.

fr:title.text: Operators cannot have more distinct eigenvalues than the dimension of its vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Operators cannot have more distinct eigenvalues than the dimension of its vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 5.12
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Corollary 7.2.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be Finite-Dimensional Vector Space over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator. Then L has at most \dim (V) distinct eigenvalues.
